section.title: Predicates
section.para: Gappa works on sets of facts about real-valued expressions. The following predicates are handled internally:

listitem.para: The value of expression x is included in interval I.
The absolute value of expression x is included in interval I.
The values of expressions x and y satisfy x = y \times (1 + \varepsilon) with \varepsilon\in I.
The value of expression x is such that \exists m \in \mathbb{Z},~x = m\cdot 2^k.
The value of expression x is such that \exists m,e \in \mathbb{Z},~x = m\cdot 2^e \land |m| < 2^k.
The value of expression x is not zero.
Expressions x and y have equal values.

section.para: In the definitions above, I denotes an interval whose bounds have known numerical values, while k is a known integer. In the description of the theorems, these parameters will usually be ignored. For instance, BND(x) just means that an enclosure of x is known. Except for NZR, all these predicates can appear in the logical formula the user wants to check. In addition, EQL properties are also used to express rewriting hints.

section.title: Theorems
section.para: There are three categories of theorems in Gappa: theorems about real arithmetic, theorems about rounding operators, and rewriting rules.

In the following, variables a, a', b, c, and d, represent arbitrary expressions. Gappa is susing backward reasoning, so they are filled by matching the goal of a theorem against the property Gappa wants to compute. If a theorem mentions both a and a' but only one of them appears on the right-hand side, then Gappa infers the other one so that a' is an approximate value of a.See for more details.
